awd_titl_txt: Culturally Responsive Indigenous Science: Connecting Land, Language, and Culture
awd_abstract_narration:
The intersection between Indigenous and Western science continues to be of great importance to K-12 science education, particularly with regards to broadening participation in STEM. With over five hundred federally recognized Native American tribes in the United States, there is much to learn and understand. This Culturally Responsive Indigenous Science project seeks to advance this knowledge base through research and by catalyzing new approaches to Indigenous science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (ISTEM) learning. Using an ISTEM focused model, the project will develop, test, and implement a culturally responsive land-based curriculum that integrates Western science, multimodal technologies and digital tools, and Native American tribal knowledge, cultures and languages to investigate and address local environmental science and sustainability concerns. While Indigenous STEM teaching and learning as constructs have existed for many years, the rigorous research design and extensive integration of multimodal technologies as platforms for scientific inquiry, data management, knowledge dissemination and curation are innovative and timely. Few, if any, Design and Development projects in the current DRK-12 portfolio explore similar work. Therefore, the broader impacts of this project are poised to not only contribute to the DRK-12 portfolio but also advance knowledge in Indigenous STEM education and science education, more broadly. 

Over a three year period, hundreds of Native American students (grades 4-9) in tribal schools located in Oregon, Washington, and Idaho will engage in the project. Each year, approximately 60-80 students (grades 7-9), with some returning students, will also participate in enrichment activities and in years 1-3, in the residential summer experience at Washington State University. A qualitative, quasi-experimental design-based study will be conducted to address three salient research questions: (a) What are the impacts of culturally responsive and land education-based ISTEM curriculum and technology on Native American student engagement, efficacy and achievement in school? (b) What types of professional development activities foster teacher efficacy and improve teacher learning and teaching of ISTEM in classrooms? and (c) How can ISTEM foster greater family and community engagement in schools and in Tribal Communities?  Data will be collected through interviews, surveys, and or questionnaires from participating students, teachers, and Tribal members. Consistent with Indigenous methodologies, focus group interviews (talking circles) will also be facilitated after ISTEM community expositions and engagement activities to capture community impacts. Formative and summative evaluations will be conducted by the Learning and Performance Research Center (LPRC) at Washington State University, an independent entity of the University with extensive expertise in project evaluation. A broad range of dissemination activities will be employed to achieve maximum impacts, including the use of the Plateau People's Web Portal, a digital tool designed to help Native communities to manage, circulate, and curate their digital materials using their own cultural protocols, language and social systems. This regional collaboration includes partnerships with the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs (Oregon), Confederated Tribes of the Colville Reservation (Washington), and the Coeur D'Alene Tribe (Idaho). 

The project is supported by the Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12), which seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

por.por_cntn:
The Culturally Responsive Indigenous Science (CRIS) project (NSF Project No. 1720931) was a collaborative effort between three Tribal communities in the Pacific Northwest (Tribal language/cultural teachers/elders/science teachers) and faculty and graduate students from the Washington State University (WSU) College of Education, College of Arts and Sciences, and the Center for Digital Scholarship and Curation (CDSC). Centering language and culture through a community and land-based approach, the project generated new approaches to Indigenous STEM teaching and learning through a focus on weaving together traditional ecological knowledge, technology, and western science in ways that honored tribal culture, language, and sovereignty while satisfying western school-based science requirements.

To accomplish the project goals and objectives, relationship building through community visits and retreats was vital to determining shared goals, milestones, and values. Five core concepts, expressed in their tribal languages, guided the project work: 1) Lifeways/way of life with Creator/spirituality, 2) Good heart/kind heart, 3) Honoring and respecting life, 4) Stewardship and being protectors, and 5) Sharing knowledge (for more detail). The outcomes accomplished under the three objectives stemming from these partnerships and collaborative values are as follows:

Objective 1: Develop and implement culturally responsive science curriculum modules that integrate Indigenous knowledge, culture and language with Western science and technology.

The Indigenous Science curriculum modules, considered a ?living curriculum? (changing and dynamic) aligned multiple lessons and interactive technological content with the land/place, language, cultural protocols, history and story unique to each Tribal community.  For example, the Water Health and Habitat module asked students to locate themselves in their Tribal community watershed, learn traditional language terms, listen to elders? stories of water health/stewardship, engage in a series of scientific observations, data collection/testing, and mapping (geovisualization) activities lessons centered on the question, ?is this water healthy?? Other lessons were developed based on each Tribe?s seasonal calendar. Simultaneously, the CDSC built the CRIS web site utilizing the Murkutu platform and the Plateau Peoples? Web Portal to ensure that the curriculum created and shared would follow ethical and cultural protocols.

Objective 2: Conduct culturally responsive professional development for teachers to effectively integrate science curriculum and technology into classroom instruction and assessment.

Numerous professional learning opportunities and teacher institutes consisted of co-teaching, co-creation of knowledge and co-supporting. Project faculty and graduate students were often positioned as learners and facilitators, as we learned about cultural nuances and Indigenous knowledge systems from Tribal elders, culture, and language educators. Project faculty, however, led the technology training sessions. Significant hours were dedicated to learning how to utilize Mukurtu, iPad applications, Geographic Information Systems for mapping, and uploading curriculum materials. Teachers were most excited about the possibilities of Interactive Content and tested games, tasks, and questions using H5P types like ?Drag the Words,? ?Find Multiple Hotspots,? ?Memory Game? and ?Interactive Video?. Teachers increased their creative use of technology, and many Native American educators indicated that this project helped them see their traditional knowledge and culture as science. 

Objective 3: Provide supplemental hands-on enrichment programs for Native American students to engage with science projects and experiments outside of the traditional school environment. 

Students from each Tribal community visited the WSU campus for field trips during the academic year and a week-long residential summer camp prior to the COVID 19 pandemic. During these visits, students engaged in hands-on science learning in labs, cultural seminars, and college preparation activities. Students stated aspirations like, ?I want to become a bear scientist? after visiting the Grizzly bear research center. When the COVID-19 pandemic surfaced, we took creative approaches to provide students with experiential Indigenous Science learning opportunities in their communities as well as virtual field trips. Once the COVID-19 restrictions lifted, we accommodated the Tribes? schedules by planning two different field trips to WSU. While many of our planned activities were halted or changed because of shut-downs and the severity of the pandemic in our communities, we were able to forge tighter connections between WSU Native American Programs and each community for sustained access to STEM pathway programs.

In conclusion, we gathered with community partners to celebrate/reflect on project accomplishments and next steps. The following themes capture those reflections: 1) It is imperative that intentional relational spaces are created for cultural values and practices, 2) Indigenous science education requires many educators with diverse expertise, 3) Flexibility is a necessity to respect Tribal and individual autonomy and timelines, and 4) All partners must actively remember who the work is designed to serve. The project afforded innovative ways of thinking about Indigenous Science and technology, teacher professional development, and student engagement. More importantly, the relationships built will continue far beyond this project.
